question.title: Problems in scaling Java swing to full screen also Windows is making it harder
question.body:
I want my program to be full screen so I use the following line of code in constructor of my frame class:

static GraphicsDevice device = GraphicsEnvironment.getLocalGraphicsEnvironment().getScreenDevices()[0];
device.setFullScreenWindow(this);

Now, I want my full screen JFrame to look something like this :

So for this I use gridBagLayout, but I had set some definite size for the components, which would be a problem when someone opens this with a monitor of different size than mine.

So I thought I should use the dimensions of the screen in which it is opened and set size using ratios of that.

But turns out :

Dimension screenSize = Toolkit.getDefaultToolkit().getScreenSize();
double width = screenSize.getWidth();
double height = screenSize.getHeight();

and

GraphicsDevice gd = GraphicsEnvironment.getLocalGraphicsEnvironment().getDefaultScreenDevice();
int width = gd.getDisplayMode().getWidth();
int height = gd.getDisplayMode().getHeight();

Both yield different results (1st one gives 1536x846 and the later gives 1920x1080).

Which one should I use? Also I learnt that windows uses Scaling of 125% and when I changed mine to 100% I got something like this :

What should I do so every Monitor displays it as the 1st image? Which resolution is the actual one and which one should I use? Any other tips for a newbie?

P.S. I found all the above code on internet and copy pasted them, don't know what much of that means.

answers.body:
Toolkit.getScreenSize() returns the scaled size, i.e., it accounts for the Windows display DPI scaling.

GraphicsDevice.getDisplayMode() returns the actual physical screen resolution — the raw number of pixels.

As you said, the reason why they are returning 2 different sizes is that, first one using 125% scale.

So use Toolkit.getDefaultToolkit().getScreenSize()

You probably should not be using setFullScreenWindow. You want to maximize your window, not take over the entire screen. Full-screen windows are usually meant for applications with custom graphics, like games. They obscure system controls like taskbars, docks, and system menubars, which is a bad thing for a regular application with input fields (like text areas) to do.

To maximize a window, use the setExtendedState method, with an argument of Frame.MAXIMIZED_BOTH. This is the same thing that happens when you double-click an application’s title bar, or press the maximize button on the end of the title bar (usually next to the ‘close window’ button).

I’m not sure what exactly you are doing with sizes, but … you should not be doing it. You should not be looking at screen sizes. You should not be doing any math to determine your components’s sizes. All of that is the job of a layout manager, like GridBagLayout.

You can just do something like this:

JPanel panel = new JPanel(new GridBagLayout());
GridBagConstraints gbc = new GridBagConstraints();
gbc.fill = GridBagConstraints.BOTH;
gbc.weightx = 1;
gbc.weighty = 1;

panel.add(new JScrollPane(jTextArea1), gbc);
panel.add(jLabel1, gbc);
// Tells GridBagLayout that this is the last component on this row.
gbc.gridwidth = GridBagConstraints.REMAINDER;
panel.add(new JScrollPane(jTextArea2), gbc);

gbc.gridwidth = 1;
panel.add(jLabel2, gbc);
panel.add(jLayeredPane, gbc);
panel.add(new JScrollPane(jTextArea3), gbc);

jFrame.getContentPane().add(panel);
jFrame.pack();
jFrame.setLocationByPlatform(true);
jFrame.setExtendedState(Frame.MAXIMIZED_BOTH);

GridBagLayout cannot force components to have the same width. The grid “cells” of a GridBagLayout are flexible: They are guaranteed to line up, but only accommodate the size of what they contain, without taking other cells into account. The easiest way to ensure the left and right sides are the same width is to create your JTextAreas with the same number of rows and columns:

jTextArea.setRows(6);
jTextArea2.setRows(6);
jTextArea3.setRows(6);
jTextArea.setColumns(20);
jTextArea2.setColumns(20);
jTextArea3.setColumns(20);

JPanel panel = new JPanel(new GridBagLayout());
// etc.

question_comments.body: Copy-n-pasting code from the internet without understanding what it does almost always leads to non-functioning and bad code. Do not do this. Instead, use the findings as "triggers" what to look up in the documentation. And use the provided tutorials. Only proceed if you understood what you did so far. Your learning curve will be steeper, but at least you learn.
Why do you size the elements by hand, if you could let the layout manager size them?

79678478.body: @Yash Please check the answer. The scaled size reflects only the Windows display DPI scaling. That is the slider in Windows setting where you can change the scaling e.g. of text between 100% and 175%. This has absolutely nothing to do with the screen size, only with the screen density.
So if I use Toolkit.getDefaultToolkit().getScreenSize(), it will always scale to the monitor, No matter the resolution or scaling value set ?

79679769.body: @Yash If you really really want to obscure the entire desktop, you can use setFullScreenWindow.  But you still should let a layout manager do its job, instead of calculating component sizes and positions yourself.
